text.p: The following are the main stories from Tuesday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG
- State premier Schroeder complains that his Social Democrats failed to mobilise voters for local elections in Lower Saxony
- Lebanese denies having started fire in refugees' hostel
- SPD ready to discuss increased police surveillance powers with government
- Fees for water supply and rubbish collection set to jump
- Greens want to change structure of chambers of commerce
- German industry association wants more support for inventors
- Germany ready to pay more into EU budget to prevent agricultural subsidies being cut
- Small bakeries going out of business
HANDELSBLATT
- Health minister Seehofer puts health insurers under pressure to cut costs
- Lower Saxony local election results are setback for state premier Schroeder
- Vebacom to use Ruhrgas gas lines for telecommunications
- Pay-TV marketing firm MMBG set to fold after Deutsche Telekom pulls out
- Mercedes says new taxes put South China van manufacturing project in danger
- Industry association BDI says German industry must get more involved in Japan
- Bayer to restructure, split German production
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG
- Greens see good chance of toppling centre-right coalition in Bonn after Lower Saxony local elections
- Prosecutors say Lebanese started fire in refugees home out of desire for revenge
- Television documentary maker admits faking films
- Bonn rejects EU Commission's financial proposals for solving BSE crisis
- Greens want to make chambers of commerce into private sector organisations
- German shares hit record high
- Hermes export credit deficit falls
- Skilled trades say top income tax rate should not exceed 35 percent
DIE WELT
- Christian Democrats says Lower Saxony local elections shift political situation in the state in their favour
- Lebanese goes on trial accused of starting fire in refugees' hostel
- Companies want to cut sick pay with immediate effect
- Pension system reserves fall far below legal limit
- Construction union IG BAU demands employers reinstate east German sectoral wage agreement but say they do not plan industrial action
- German cattle farmers criticise EU's BSE proposals
- Skilled trades federation demands more budget savings
- Britons at odds over single currency
-- Bonn Newsroom +49 228 2609760
